posts.name:
Rodrigo Bidinoto
Rodrigo Bidinoto
posts.content:
One of the largest economies in the world, Brazil is the land of opportunity for B2B SaaS. In the growth at all cost mode, so many companies tried to expand to Brazil and failed.

Why? Here are the main 5 reasons:

1) Understanding Brazilian Uncertainty
Uncertainty is the norm in Brazil. We prefer to keep cash on hand so that we can do something when a crisis hits - which will happen sooner than later.
90's inflation molded the Brazilian thinking when it comes to money and understanding this context is important to create a price and package offer to the Brazilian market.

2) Relationship over anything
Success in the Brazilian market often depends on building meaningful, long-term relationships. Local teams, familiar with the nuances of the culture, are indispensable. As well as building relationships with local partners who not only will be extremely important in the sales motion but also in building some of the technological gaps that a global player won‚Äôt for lack of scalability.

3) High service expectation - with low cost or preferably free
Brazilian customers have incredibly high expectations for service. It‚Äôs not just about offering a good product; it‚Äôs about providing ongoing, exceptional support. And here‚Äôs the twist: they expect all of this at minimal cost‚Äîor ideally, for free. This mindset stems from a deeply ingrained expectation that service is part of the package, not an extra. To succeed, you need to invest in scalable, efficient service models, while making sure that customers feel they‚Äôre receiving premium treatment without breaking the bank.

4) Brazilian Ecosystem matters
Brazilian ecosystem itself is unique, with a strong presence of local solutions and partnerships. Global players often miss the mark by failing to tap into this ecosystem of local providers, startups, and integrators - which is pretty unique - that help bridge gaps in technology and services.

5) Navigating Regulatory Complexity
Brazil‚Äôs regulatory environment is one of the most complex in the world. Tax rules differ significantly between states, labor laws are one the strictest globally, and we have our own privacy regulations like LGPD (Brazil‚Äôs version of GDPR).

Despite this complex and unique environment, Brazil is one of the largest economies in the world, making the potential rewards for entering this market incredibly high. However, it‚Äôs not an easy path. Succeeding in Brazil demands more effort, adaptation, and understanding than most other markets.

comments.commentText: Brands that go international (as early as you can) and get those footprints in key markets like Brazil get such a competitive advantage. Couldn‚Äôt agree more
True, this is another great point.

OpenAI CEO Sam Altman on the future of AI:

"People will lose jobs. But many new jobs will be created, much better jobs. Not everyone's gonna like all of the impacts, but this is coming. This is like a scientific achievement of humanity that is gonna get embedded in everything we do‚Äù - Sam Altman

I guess UBI is inevitable now...

comments.commentText: Many people will lose their jobs, but adaptation is key. The ability to adapt will determine whether someone grows or remains stagnant.
Maury Rogow, CEO I agree! No other way!

I appreciate your succinct agreement, Dhvani. It often takes a shared perspective to highlight the importance of aligning our professional narratives effectively on LinkedIn. Your insights are always valuable.
